text: The curious tale of programmers wanting to turn other people into ... programmers!

elements.text: The curious tale of programmers wanting to turn other people into ... programmers!

text:
I also like the resulting layout, let me reflect on why. I might be stating the obvious here, but anyway. Newspaper nostalgia aside, I like how you found a meaningful use for the advancement in screen technology. This layout would never have worked back on a 640*480 CRT, but today I'm on a 27 inch high-res screen (almost as large as a newspaper?), and yet many modern apps & websites just waste that space, they use it for whitespace/margins and slightly smoother icons. Instead, you are fitting more content on screen! Browsing different articles by moving my gaze is inherently faster and easier than browsing by clicking a link and waiting for a new page to load.

And I like that it works on phone too. The headlines are large enough to read, and then I can zoom in to read the rest. Double-tapping in Chrome on Android also does... some kind of zoom, maybe not exactly a "column zoom" like iOS, but still useful in this layout. Regarding ease-of-use, zooming/panning is in the same ballpark as tapping a link to a new article.

As a side effect, I got to read some interesting articles on your site, thanks!

text:
Thanks for the feedback, I'm glad you liked it! :blush: As another non-native English speaker, I often have the same difficulty as you. I still need to work on my pronunciation - "function" tends to come out as "fanction", and I sometimes mix up "two" and "to" which might be confusing to viewers. To compensate, I provide proper subtitles instead of YouTube's auto-generated ones.

Does anyone have feedback on the ideas / prototypes in episode 2, 3 or 4? :pray:

elements.text: Thanks for the feedback, I'm glad you liked it!

To compensate, I provide proper subtitles instead of YouTube's auto-generated ones.

Does anyone have feedback on the ideas / prototypes in episode 2, 3 or 4?

text: I'll have to test on the wife's droid one of these days. I love the iPhone reading experience and need to try and bring that to desktop.

elements.text: I'll have to test on the wife's droid one of these days. I love the iPhone reading experience and need to try and bring that to desktop.

text: Btw my trick for the design is to rip off "The New York Times Complete Front Pages: 1851-2018". Figure 170 years of the best readers/writers/editors/printers in the world can't be wrong! The fact that I can read the paper from 1851 as enjoyable as today's paper is a sign of good design

text: The random access and high level reading is definitely the goal. Plenty of existing solutions for one by one article reading

elements.text: The random access and high level reading is definitely the goal. Plenty of existing solutions for one by one article reading

text:
I've only watched 1 & 2 so far (yes, the videos are short, but this community drops a _lot_ of reading on my plate, haha).

For #2, I found the scaling text to be... the sort of thing that is very hard to appreciate without actually working directly with. I recently went through a period where I used semantic highlighting (instead of syntax highlighting), since it was also the sort of thing that seems good in the abstract but is hard to understand without living with. It didn't stick — I'm back with syntax highlighting — because the plugin that I used didn't produce colors that were as visually pleasing as my syntax highlighting. If I'm going to be staring at something all day, I want it to be comfortable (for the same reason I don't want an uncomfortable chair, even if it might help me stay more alert, say). So if I were to actually try the scaling text, I might find that I like it. But it'd be very hard for me to evaluate it unless it were quite polished. That's a catch-22. The demo in the video did a good job presenting the thinking behind the idea, but the implementation (as captured by the video, at least) was too.. detached from my reality... for me to really develop a sense of it.

But then, I'm sort of a stick in the mud when it comes to text, hah. So I'm excited to watch some of your more visual prototype videos when I get the chance.

text: One thing to do with text is to keep it fixed-size while scaling other representations.  With some VR stuff we were doing, all the labels were composited separately from the scene so as to be as readable as possible.  Since you don't want the text too close, we ended up with the weird effect where an object could be in-front of its label, which would still be visible since it's rendered on top.  (I guess a similar thing happens with AR all the time, but that sort of glitch feels different since the goal is to have the AR model be embedded into the scene rather than ghost overlaid.)

elements.text: One thing to do with text is to keep it fixed-size while scaling other representations.  With some VR stuff we were doing, all the labels were composited separately from the scene so as to be as readable as possible.  Since you don't want the text too close, we ended up with the weird effect where an object could be in-front of its label, which would still be visible since it's rendered on top.  (I guess a similar thing happens with AR all the time, but that sort of glitch feels different since the goal is to have the AR model be embedded into the scene rather than ghost overlaid.)
